text: Your Weekend BriefingHere’s what you need to know about the week’s top stories.
The Book Review PodcastJeffrey Toobin on President Trump; Elena Ferrante’s new novel.
Listen to New SongsHear tracks by SZA, Ava Max, Tricky, Bill Callahan and others.

In Final Stretch, Biden Defends Lead Against Trump’s OnslaughtPresident Trump is attempting to overtake Joe Biden with a strategy of racial polarization as the campaign enters an intense phase.Mr. Trump’s effort to revive his candidacy has jolted Mr. Biden into a more proactive posture, one that some Democrats have long urged him to adopt.
Vice President Joseph R. Biden Jr. met with Xi Jinping, then the vice president of China, in Dujiangyan, China, in 2011. Peter Parks/Agence France-Presse — Getty Images

More Than Ever, Trump Casts Himself as the Defender of White AmericaPresenting himself as a warrior against identity politics, the president has made appeals to the grievances of white supporters a centerpiece of his campaign.
President Trump made racist insults and was driven by hatred for President Obama, Michael Cohen writes in his book.
A New Front in America’s Pandemic: College TownsThe potential spread of the virus has exacerbated tensions as towns try to balance economic dependence on universities with public health fears.
Daily Coronavirus Testing at Home? Many Experts Are SkepticalThe buzzy idea is impractical, critics said. And there isn’t yet real-world data to show it will work.
Search for colleges here

Kamala Harris Expresses Distrust of President Trump on Vaccine SafetySenator Kamala Harris said she would only get a vaccine if experts said it was safe. Experts urge caution at Labor Day celebrations. Here’s the latest.
Helicopters Rescue About 200 Trapped in California WildfireAbout 20 people were injured in the Creek Fire, which broke out Friday in the Sierra National Forest and consumed more than 45,000 acres.
Novak Djokovic Out of U.S. Open After Accidental Hit of Line JudgeDjokovic, the No. 1 seed in the men’s draw, was disqualified after a lengthy discussion with officials.

Listen Closely, and You Will Hear Coaching During U.S. Open MatchesWith no fans in the seats this year, there is chatter galore between coaches and players on the court, even though it breaks the rules.

A Weapon for Extortion Long Ignored in Alabama Prisons: CellphonesFamilies say they have been threatened by call and text into sending thousands of dollars to protect loved ones on the inside. Some died anyway.
Krista DiamondThe Strange Grief of Losing My Sense of TasteMany symptoms of Covid-19 were difficult, but losing my ability to taste hurt the most.
Steven GreenhouseDonald J. Trump and the Republican Party vs. WorkersSupport for unions is rising. The G.O.P. might want to be part of that.
Pico IyerThe Best Reason to Go to College
Binyamin Appelbaum and photographs by Damon WinterCan a Person’s Hands Reveal Their Job?
The Editorial BoardHow Many of These 68,000 Deaths Could Have Been Avoided?
Terence NanceTo My Missed Connection: I Saw You Walk Into the Guisados on Sunset

Endurance Racing With Cars That Belong in a Demolition DerbyAutos worth $500 or less have competed for years in a race called 24 Hours of Lemons. Now electric vehicles have been invited, with no limit on spending.
This Labor Day, These Workers Are Trying to Stay AfloatAn artist, bookseller, comedian and five others share their stories of how they are coping with all the uncertainty amid the pandemic.

Famous in Italy, Rodari Reaches U.S. Shores With ‘Telephone Tales’The children’s book writer never caught on in America, partly because of his Communist Party ties, but a new release of his masterpiece could change that.
